block.p: TURKEY, ARMENIA: PRAISE AND REGRET Turkey praised the United States Congress's abandonment of a resolution accusing Turks of genocide against Armenians 85 years ago, but Armenia said it regretted the action. Turkey said the move had removed a major threat to Turkish-American relations. A spokesman for Armenia's Foreign Ministry, Ara Papyan, said Armenia again appealed to Turkey for direct talks to resolve the issue.

FRANCE: GO-AHEAD TO TRY QADDAFI A court ruled that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya could be prosecuted in France for the bombing of a French airliner over Niger in 1989, in which 170 people died. The court rejected the argument that Colonel Qaddafi had immunity as a head of state. Instead, the court said he could be brought to court for ''complicity in murder in relation to a terrorist act.''

FRANCE: 'SEX TOURIST' CONVICTED A Frenchman was found guilty of raping an 11-year-old girl during a ''sex holiday'' in Thailand and sentenced to seven years in prison. Amnon Chemouil, a public transport worker, was the first person to stand trial before a French jury under a law passed in 1994 to combat ''sex tourism.'' It allows suspects in rape cases involving minors abroad to be prosecuted in France.

RUSSIA: DIVERS REACH THE KURSK Divers sent to recover the bodies of 118 sailors aboard the sunken Russian submarine said they could be ready to start rescue efforts within a day after an examination of the wreck by a mini-sub showed no signs of radiation leakage. But the commander of the Russian Navy warned that he would cancel the effort, which teams Russian, British and Norwegian divers, should it appear too dangerous.

VATICAN: PATRON SAINT OF POLITICIANS Sir Thomas More, whose defiance of King Henry VIII cost him his life, will be proclaimed patron saint of politicians. The Vatican said Pope John Paul II had prepared the proclamation as part of Holy Year ceremonies next month. Details of the proclamation will be given at a Vatican news conference attended by a member of the House of Lords, Lord David Alton.

MYANMAR: BRITON FREED A Briton sentenced to 17 years in prison last year after distributing pro-democracy leaflets and publicly criticizing the government has been released after an international campaign on his behalf, Britain said. In announcing the release of James Mawdsley, 27, Foreign Secretary Robin Cook said, ''James's only crime was to highlight the suppression of ethnic minorities in Burma and to call for democratic change.'' He is to return to Britain today.

SRI LANKA: JOURNALIST KILLED Gunmen killed Maivaganan Nimalarajan, 40, a Tamil journalist in Jaffna who reported vote fraud in recent elections. He was shot as he sat in his study; his wife and three daughters, in another room, were unhurt, but his parents were wounded by a grenade blast.

AFGHANISTAN: REFUGEES FLEE TO PAKISTAN With intense fighting reported in the northeast between the Taliban and opposition forces, thousands of Afghan refugees have fled into neighboring Pakistan, the office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees said. Nearly 23,000 Afghan refugees have sought asylum in Pakistan in recent weeks.

SOMALIA: NEW CABINET NAMED Prime Minister Ali Khalif Galaydh named his cabinet, offering no posts to any of the warlords who have vowed to block the newly elected president, Abdiqassim Salad Hassan, left, from setting up a government. The cabinet includes members from all of Somalia's major clans but offers no concessions to warlords in the capital, Mogadishu, or the breakaway northern regions, Somaliland and Puntland.

SOUTH AFRICA: CHOLERA ON RISE Health workers in KwaZulu-Natal Province are continuing to record new cases of cholera as a deadly outbreak of the water-borne sickness enters its third month. So far 3,279 cases been reported and 27 people have died, the health department said.

BOLIVIA: CABINET SHUFFLE Facing a rising economic crisis, President Hugo Banzer shuffled seven posts in his cabinet. Most of the officials simply moved to other positions, although there will be two new ministers. Mr. Banzer is now preparing a new economic plan, which will include a change in tax structure and new job programs.

ARGENTINA: SPY CHIEF QUITS The head of Argentina's spy agency, who has been under fire for criticizing the governing coalition and suspected of involvement in Senate bribes, has quit, a government spokesman said. Fernando de Santibanes offered his resignation under pressure from within the coalition after a newspaper interpreted comments he made as a call for President Fernando de la Rua to abandon his junior coalition partner.

CYPRUS: GREEK-TURKISH AIR INCIDENT Mock dogfights between Greek and Turkish warplanes broke out close to Cyprus as the Greek planes were heading to the divided island for military maneuvers, the Cypriot Defense Ministry said. It said there had been two incidents between Rhodes and Cyprus, when Turkish jets apparently buzzed two Greek F-16 aircraft and two A-7 Corsair bombers. Other reports suggested that 12 Turkish aircraft had been headed off by an equal number of Greek jets.
